wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the AR backend application. Explain its purpose as a FastAPI-based service for AR content management, multi-tenant company administration, and storage orchestration. Describe the core capabilities including NFT generation, video scheduling, automated backups, and monitoring. Document the architectural style (modular, domain-driven), key components (API layer, storage adapters, background schedulers), and system boundaries. Highlight integration points with mobile clients, Yandex.Disk, MinIO, and monitoring stack. Include high-level diagrams illustrating system context and component interactions. Provide a conceptual walkthrough of user workflows for administrators, developers, and DevOps engineers. Make the content accessible to beginners while establishing technical context for advanced users.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive Docker deployment documentation for the AR backend application. Detail the use of docker-compose for orchestrating services including the main application, MinIO for remote storage, monitoring stack (Prometheus, Grafana, Alertmanager), and testing environments. Explain service dependencies, network configuration, volume mounts, and environment variable injection. Provide examples of starting, stopping, and scaling services. Include best practices for image building, container security, and production optimizations. Address common issues such as container networking, persistent storage, and log management.

wiki_catalogs.name: AR Content Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for AR Content Management, covering the creation, retrieval, tracking, and deletion of AR content. Explain the data model including fields like image_path, video_path, marker files (fset, fset3, iset), ar_url, and QR code generation. Document the API endpoints for CRUD operations, view/click tracking, and public AR page rendering. Include integration with NFT generation pipeline and marker file processing. Provide examples from the codebase showing how AR content is stored, accessed, and served through the ar_page.html template. Address security considerations for public access endpoints and performance implications of media file handling. Discuss use cases such as marketing campaigns and interactive media where AR content is leveraged.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Authentication API endpoints. Document the JWT-based authentication flow including registration, login, logout, token refresh, and password change operations. Include detailed request/response schemas, HTTP methods, and URL patterns for each endpoint. Explain the authentication mechanisms (Bearer token and authToken cookie), rate limiting (5/minute), and account lockout policies after failed attempts. Provide curl examples for common operations and security considerations such as password validation rules (minimum 8 characters with letters and numbers) and token expiration. Address error handling for invalid credentials, locked accounts, and expired tokens, including the 423 Locked status code for locked accounts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for mobile authentication endpoints. Detail the POST /auth/login and POST /auth/logout endpoints with HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, and authentication methods. Document the JWT-based authentication flow, token expiration (1800 seconds), and secure storage recommendations for mobile platforms (Keychain for iOS, KeyStore for Android, flutter_secure_storage for Flutter, react-native-keychain for React Native). Include implementation examples in Swift, Kotlin, and TypeScript showing proper request formatting, error handling for 401 Unauthorized, 423 Locked, and 429 Too Many Requests responses, and token refresh strategies. Address security considerations including HTTPS enforcement, rate limiting (5 requests/minute), and secure token storage. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like token expiration, invalid credentials, and account lockout scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Storage Adapter Pattern
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Storage Adapter Pattern implementation in the Vertex AR system. Explain how the pattern enables pluggable storage backends (local, MinIO, Yandex.Disk) through a unified interface. Detail the base StorageAdapter class and its concrete implementations: LocalStorageAdapter, MinioStorageAdapter, and YandexDiskStorageAdapter. Document the interface contracts including save_file, get_file, delete_file, file_exists, and get_public_url methods. Include code examples showing how different adapters are instantiated and used within the StorageManager. Illustrate the benefits of this pattern for extensibility, testability, and runtime flexibility. Address error handling strategies, performance characteristics, and security considerations specific to each adapter type. Provide guidance on implementing new storage adapters by extending the base class.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Mechanisms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication mechanisms in the AR backend application. Thoroughly explain the JWT-based authentication flow, including token issuance, validation, and revocation. Document the implementation of password hashing using SHA256 and verification logic. Describe the session management system using in-memory token storage with thread-safe access. Explain the authentication endpoint structure, request/response schemas, and error handling (401 Unauthorized, 423 Locked). Include code examples from the actual implementation showing how login attempts are processed, tokens are generated, and user context is extracted. Detail the integration between the FastAPI security dependency and the custom TokenManager class. Address common issues such as token expiration, concurrent session handling, and lockout state cleanup. Provide performance considerations for token validation at scale and thread-safety guarantees in multi-threaded environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Video Animation Scheduler
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Video Animation Scheduler sub-component. Thoroughly explain implementation details, including the initialization process, execution patterns using asyncio, and interaction with the main FastAPI application through the get_database method. Document the configuration options from settings (VIDEO_SCHEDULER_ENABLED, VIDEO_SCHEDULER_CHECK_INTERVAL, etc.) and their impact on scheduler behavior. Explain the core functionality of checking due activations and deactivations, handling video rotation (sequential and cyclic), and archiving expired videos. Detail the relationship with the database layer for retrieving videos due for activation/deactivation and updating video states. Describe the notification system integration for activation, deactivation, rotation, and archiving events via Telegram and email. Include concrete examples from the codebase, such as the start_video_animation_scheduler method's infinite loop with error handling and sleep intervals. Address common issues like database connection failures during scheduler execution and provide solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on topics like the scheduler's error handling strategy and resource utilization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Prometheus Metrics Export
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Prometheus metrics export system. Detail all exported metrics including system-level (CPU, memory, disk, network), service health, application performance, and deep diagnostics metrics. Explain the metric naming conventions, label structures, and data types. Document the update interval and collection mechanism. Provide examples of key metrics like vertex_ar_cpu_usage_percent, vertex_ar_memory_usage_bytes, and vertex_ar_slow_queries_count. Include configuration requirements in prometheus.yml for scraping the application. Explain how to create custom queries and alerts based on these metrics. Address common issues with metric collection and provide troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for unit testing in the Vertex AR project. Explain the purpose of unit tests in isolating individual components such as API endpoints, data models, and service functions. Document the use of pytest with markers like @pytest.mark.unit and fixture-based setup via conftest.py. Include examples from actual test files such as test_auth.py and test_models.py to demonstrate mocking, parameterized testing, and assertion patterns. Describe how unit tests validate business logic, input validation using Pydantic, and database model behaviors. Address common issues like test isolation, dependency injection, and handling asynchronous functions. Provide performance considerations for fast execution and integration into development workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Variables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for environment variable configuration in the Vertex AR application. Detail all available environment variables, their purposes, default values, and security implications. Explain the configuration hierarchy between development, staging, and production environments using the provided .env examples. Document critical security variables like SECRET_KEY, JWT tokens, and database credentials, emphasizing secure handling practices. Cover application settings (DEBUG, BASE_URL, APP_HOST/PORT), storage configurations (STORAGE_TYPE, MINIO settings), security parameters (CORS_ORIGINS, rate limiting), monitoring thresholds (CPU, memory, disk), and service-specific configurations for email, Telegram, and backup systems. Include practical examples of environment files for different deployment scenarios and provide troubleshooting guidance for common configuration issues like connection timeouts, authentication failures, and performance bottlenecks. Address the deprecation of environment-based SMTP credentials and migration to the secure admin UI configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Content Types Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the 'content_types' section in storage_config.json. Explain how each content type (portraits, videos, previews, nft_markers) is individually configurable with storage_type and Yandex.Disk integration settings. Document the purpose of each content type within the AR workflow, valid storage_type values ('local', 'yandex_disk', 'minio'), and the implications of enabling Yandex.Disk synchronization with custom base_path configurations. Provide real-world examples showing how to configure hybrid storage strategies where portraits use local storage while videos are stored on Yandex.Disk. Include validation rules enforced by the application, such as required base_path patterns and storage_type constraints, and explain error handling for misconfigured content types during application startup.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for application-level environment variables in the Vertex AR system. Detail all configuration options including DEBUG mode, SECRET_KEY for JWT token security, APP_HOST/APP_PORT for network binding, BASE_URL for AR content generation, and ENVIRONMENT for deployment context. Explain the purpose and security implications of each setting, with emphasis on production requirements like disabling debug mode and using secure random keys. Document the internal health check URL configuration and its role in monitoring systems. Include practical examples from both development and production .env files, showing how these variables affect application behavior. Address common configuration issues such as incorrect URL settings leading to broken AR links or security vulnerabilities from exposed debug modes. Provide troubleshooting guidance for connection issues related to host/port configuration and version management through the VERSION file.

wiki_catalogs.name: Local Storage Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for configuring local storage in the Vertex AR system. Detail the STORAGE_TYPE environment variable and its valid value 'local' to activate local storage backend. Explain the STORAGE_ROOT path derived from BASE_DIR and its default location within the application directory. Document how the system ensures directory creation via mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True) in the Settings class. Include configuration parameters such as file permissions, disk space requirements, and performance considerations for high-I/O operations. Provide examples from .env files showing proper local storage setup. Address common issues like insufficient disk space, permission denied errors, and cross-platform path compatibility. Include troubleshooting steps for file access failures and performance optimization tips such as using SSD storage and proper filesystem selection. Explain integration points with upload endpoints, preview generation, and backup systems that rely on local storage paths.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Security
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for authentication-related security settings in the Vertex AR application. Cover session management via SESSION_TIMEOUT_MINUTES, brute force protection using AUTH_MAX_ATTEMPTS and AUTH_LOCKOUT_MINUTES, and JWT token validity through TOKEN_EXPIRATION_HOURS. Explain the implementation of rate limiting for authentication endpoints (AUTH_RATE_LIMIT) and its interaction with the global rate limiter. Document the secure handling of DEFAULT_ADMIN credentials and the risks of using default passwords in production. Include code examples from auth.py showing how failed login attempts are tracked and accounts are locked. Provide secure configuration examples for production, including recommended lockout durations and token expiration policies. Address common misconfigurations such as insufficient lockout periods, excessively long token lifetimes, and disabled rate limiting. Include guidance on rotating admin credentials and monitoring authentication logs for suspicious activity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Email Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for email service integration in the Vertex AR application. Detail the configuration of SMTP_SERVER, SMTP_PORT, EMAIL_FROM, and ADMIN_EMAILS environment variables with valid examples for Gmail, Outlook, and custom SMTP providers. Explain the deprecation of SMTP_USERNAME and SMTP_PASSWORD due to security risks, referencing the migration to encrypted database-backed storage via the admin UI. Provide step-by-step instructions for configuring SMTP credentials through the Notification Settings interface, including generating app-specific passwords for Gmail. Document the EMAIL_QUEUE_WORKERS setting for controlling concurrent email processing and explain the EMAIL_MAX_RETRIES mechanism with exponential backoff. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as authentication failures, TLS/SSL handshake errors, rate limiting, and blocked ports. Highlight security best practices, including the use of app-specific passwords, firewall configuration, and monitoring outbound email traffic. Reference logs and diagnostic commands for verifying email delivery and debugging failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Uvicorn Server Tuning
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for tuning Uvicorn server settings in the Vertex AR application. Detail the configuration and impact of UVICORN_WORKERS (auto-calculated based on CPU count), UVICORN_KEEPALIVE_TIMEOUT (connection persistence), UVICORN_LIMIT_CONCURRENCY (maximum concurrent connections), and UVICORN_BACKLOG (connection queue size). Explain the role of UVICORN_PROXY_HEADERS in reverse proxy environments and UVICORN_TIMEOUT_GRACEFUL_SHUTDOWN for controlled service restarts. Provide real-world configuration examples for different deployment scales, from development environments to high-traffic production systems. Include performance benchmarks, connection handling strategies, and recommendations for optimizing throughput versus resource consumption. Address common issues such as worker timeouts, connection queuing delays, and graceful shutdown failures. Document integration with systemd and Docker deployment scenarios, and provide monitoring metrics to validate tuning effectiveness.

wiki_catalogs.name: System Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the system monitoring subsystem in the Vertex AR application. Detail the implementation of the SystemMonitor class that tracks CPU, memory, disk, and network usage using psutil. Explain how metrics are collected at configurable intervals defined by HEALTH_CHECK_INTERVAL and how threshold-based alerts are triggered for CPU_THRESHOLD, MEMORY_THRESHOLD, and DISK_THRESHOLD. Document the data collection methods including get_cpu_usage(), get_memory_usage(), get_disk_usage(), and get_network_stats() with their respective return structures. Cover the integration with Prometheus metrics through the prometheus_metrics.py module and how metrics are exposed via the /metrics endpoint. Include configuration examples for different deployment scenarios and explain how to interpret the collected metrics for performance analysis. Address common issues such as high CPU load patterns, memory leaks, and disk I/O bottlenecks, providing troubleshooting guidance and optimization recommendations.

wiki_catalogs.name: CPU Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for CPU monitoring in the Vertex AR application. Explain the implementation of the get_cpu_usage() method that collects CPU utilization metrics using psutil, including overall percentage, per-core usage, load averages, and top CPU-consuming processes. Document how the HEALTH_CHECK_INTERVAL setting controls the frequency of CPU checks and how the CPU_THRESHOLD triggers alerts when exceeded. Describe the integration with Prometheus for exposing CPU metrics via the /metrics endpoint and how these metrics are visualized in Grafana. Include configuration examples for adjusting CPU thresholds and handling high-load scenarios. Address common issues such as sustained high CPU usage, inefficient processes, and load balancing strategies, providing troubleshooting steps and optimization recommendations based on real-world scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Process History Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the process history tracking feature in the Vertex AR monitoring system. Detail the implementation of the process history ring buffer that stores CPU and RSS (Resident Set Size) snapshots for each monitored process. Explain how the track_process_snapshot method captures process metrics and maintains a fixed-size history based on MONITORING_PROCESS_HISTORY_SIZE configuration. Document the data structure format for process snapshots including timestamp, CPU percentage, and memory usage in MB. Describe how the get_hotspots method aggregates this data to calculate trends such as average, minimum, and maximum values. Include configuration examples showing different retention strategies and explain how to use this data to identify processes with abnormal resource consumption patterns. Address common issues such as memory overhead from tracking too many processes and provide guidance on tuning the history size for different deployment environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the alert stabilization configuration in the Vertex AR system. Explain the purpose and default values of key environment variables: MONITORING_CONSECUTIVE_FAILURES (controls the number of consecutive failures required before alert escalation), MONITORING_DEDUP_WINDOW (defines the deduplication window in seconds to prevent alert spam), and ALERT_RECOVERY_MINUTES (controls notification of service recovery). Document how these settings can be overridden via database-persisted configurations through the _load_persisted_settings method in SystemMonitor. Provide examples of configuration scenarios for different environments (development, staging, production) and explain the impact of various threshold combinations. Include guidance on how to modify these settings safely and the importance of aligning MONITORING_CONSECUTIVE_FAILURES with HEALTH_CHECK_INTERVAL for appropriate detection timing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Telegram Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Telegram alert integration in Vertex AR. Explain the implementation of the send_telegram_alert method in the AlertManager class, including its use of the Telegram Bot API to send formatted Markdown messages with emoji indicators for severity levels. Document the configuration hierarchy that first attempts to retrieve bot_token and chat_ids from the database via get_telegram_config, falling back to environment variables (TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN, TELEGRAM_CHAT_ID) when not configured. Detail the error handling and retry logic for failed messages, including logging to notification_history with status and error details. Provide configuration examples for setting up multiple chat recipients and explain how to troubleshoot common issues such as invalid bot tokens, network timeouts, and message formatting errors. Include code examples showing successful and failed delivery scenarios from the logs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the AR backend. Detail the primary framework (FastAPI) and ASGI server (Uvicorn), ORM (SQLAlchemy), and data validation (Pydantic). Explain the role of each major dependency: Prometheus for monitoring, MinIO SDK for S3-compatible storage, Yandex.Disk API for remote integration, psutil for system metrics, and Jinja2 for templating. Document version compatibility, dependency management via pyproject.toml and requirements files, and security audit processes. Include practical examples of how these technologies are instantiated and used in the codebase (e.g., FastAPI app initialization, Pydantic model validation). Address rationale behind technology choices and their impact on performance, scalability, and developer experience.

wiki_catalogs.name: Systemd Service Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for systemd service configuration used to manage backup processes in the AR application. Explain the structure and purpose of the vertex-ar-backup.service and associated timer, including execution frequency, user permissions, and logging. Document integration with the application's backup scheduler and shell scripts. Provide instructions for installing, enabling, starting, and monitoring the service. Include troubleshooting tips for common systemd issues such as failed startups, permission errors, and log inspection via journalctl.

wiki_catalogs.name: Multi-Company Tenancy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Multi-Company Tenancy, explaining how the system supports isolated company environments within a shared infrastructure. Document the Company model, its relationship with users, clients, and storage configurations. Explain API endpoints for company management, client provisioning, and cross-company access controls. Cover configuration inheritance, customizable contact fields, and storage defaults per company. Include real-world usage scenarios where enterprises manage multiple brands or subsidiaries. Provide code examples showing company isolation logic in database queries and API access restrictions. Address data privacy requirements and administrative workflows for managing multi-tenant environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the User Management API endpoints. Document the admin-only user management operations including creating, reading, updating, and deleting users with proper role-based access control. Include detailed request/response schemas, HTTP methods, and URL patterns for user profile management, user listing with filtering by role and status, and password change functionality. Explain the admin authentication requirement for all endpoints and the soft-delete implementation. Provide examples for user creation with role assignment and profile updates. Address security considerations such as password change requiring current password verification and automatic token revocation on password change to force re-authentication on other devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for all mobile-specific endpoints. Document the GET /portraits, GET /portraits/{permanent_link}, POST /portraits/{portrait_id}/view, GET /companies, and GET /portraits/{portrait_id}/marker-status endpoints with their respective HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters, and response schemas. Explain the purpose of each endpoint: portrait listing with filtering by company_id or client_id, public portrait access via permanent links, view tracking for analytics, company listing with portrait counts, and NFT marker status checking. Include examples of request/response pairs for each endpoint, query parameters (page, page_size, include_inactive), and error handling strategies. Document the MobilePortraitResponse, PortraitsListResponse, ViewResponse, CompanyInfo, and MarkerStatusResponse models with all their fields and data types. Address performance considerations for mobile networks including pagination defaults (20 items/page) and optimized data payloads.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for storage configuration management in the Vertex AR system. Explain how storage settings are managed through both JSON configuration files (storage_config.json) and environment variables. Document the hierarchical configuration system that supports global defaults and company-specific overrides. Detail the configuration schema including content_types, backup_settings, yandex_disk, and minio sections. Explain how the system handles configuration loading, validation, and fallback mechanisms. Include examples of configuration files and environment variable setups for different deployment scenarios. Describe the runtime configuration reloading capability and how changes propagate to storage adapters. Address security considerations for storing sensitive credentials and best practices for configuration management in different environments (development, staging, production).

wiki_catalogs.name: Role-Based Access Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the role-based access control system in the AR backend application. Explain how user roles (admin, user, company_admin) are defined and enforced across API endpoints. Document the implementation of role checking in middleware and decorator patterns. Describe how permissions are extracted from JWT tokens and validated before route execution. Include examples from protected endpoints in the admin and user management APIs. Explain the relationship between user roles and data isolation, particularly in multi-company scenarios. Address common issues such as privilege escalation attempts, improper role assignment, and missing permission checks. Provide guidance on extending the role system with new roles or granular permissions. Include performance considerations for permission checking and caching strategies for frequently accessed authorization data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lifecycle Scheduler
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Project Lifecycle Scheduler sub-component. Thoroughly explain implementation details, including the initialization process, execution patterns using asyncio, and interaction with the main application through the get_database method. Document the configuration options from settings (LIFECYCLE_SCHEDULER_ENABLED, LIFECYCLE_CHECK_INTERVAL_SECONDS, etc.) and their impact on scheduler behavior. Explain the core functionality of calculating lifecycle statuses (active, expiring, archived) based on subscription deadlines and updating portrait statuses in the database. Detail the time-based notification system for 7-day, 24-hour, and post-expiry alerts, including the logic in should_send_* methods and the send_* notification methods. Describe the integration with the email service for sending client notifications and the Telegram alert system for admin notifications. Explain the relationship with the database layer for retrieving portraits for lifecycle checks and updating notification sent flags. Include concrete examples from the codebase, such as the calculate_lifecycle_status method's business logic and the start_lifecycle_scheduler method's infinite loop with error handling. Address common issues like timezone handling in subscription_end datetime parsing and provide solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on topics like the notification persistence mechanism and error recovery in the scheduling loop.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alerting Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the alerting management system. Thoroughly explain the alert configuration in Alertmanager, including route definitions, receivers, and notification templates. Document the alert deduplication mechanism using consecutive failure thresholds and deduplication windows. Explain how alert severity levels (warning, medium, high) are determined based on threshold overshoot. Include configuration options for different notification channels and escalation policies. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how alerts are triggered and processed. Address common issues like alert storms and their solutions through proper threshold tuning. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Integration Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for integration testing in the Vertex AR system. Thoroughly explain how integration tests verify interactions between components such as API endpoints, database layers, storage adapters, and authentication flows. Use real examples from test_api_endpoints.py and test_ar_functionality.py to illustrate end-to-end request handling, session management, and state transitions. Document the use of test clients, database rollback strategies, and external service simulation. Explain how tests validate multi-step workflows like user login, AR content upload, and backup initiation. Address common challenges including test data setup, race conditions, and environment consistency. Include performance tips for minimizing test duration while maintaining coverage across critical paths.

wiki_catalogs.name: JSON Configuration Files
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the JSON-based configuration system in Vertex AR. Focus on the structure and purpose of storage_config.json, explaining each configuration section including content_types (portraits, videos, previews, nft_markers), backup_settings, yandex_disk, and minio configurations. Document the hierarchical configuration approach where JSON files provide detailed storage policies while environment variables control high-level settings. Explain how to configure Yandex.Disk integration with OAuth tokens and base paths, set up backup parameters like auto_split_backups and compression, and manage MinIO connections. Provide examples of configuration scenarios for different storage strategies (local-only, hybrid with Yandex.Disk, MinIO-only) and include validation rules and error handling for malformed JSON configurations. Address the relationship between JSON configuration files and runtime application behavior, including reload mechanisms and validation checks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backup Settings Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the 'backup_settings' section in storage_config.json. Detail each parameter: auto_split_backups (boolean control for splitting large backups), max_backup_size_mb (threshold for triggering split), chunk_size_mb (size of individual backup chunks), and compression (supported formats like 'gz'). Explain how these settings interact during backup execution, including the algorithm for calculating splits and applying compression. Provide configuration examples for different use cases (e.g., high-frequency small backups vs. infrequent large archives) and document performance implications of various settings. Include information on how backup settings are validated at runtime and errors handled when invalid values are provided (e.g., chunk_size_mb exceeding max_backup_size_mb).

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for security-related environment variables in the Vertex AR application. Cover authentication settings including SESSION_TIMEOUT_MINUTES, AUTH_MAX_ATTEMPTS, and AUTH_LOCKOUT_MINUTES for brute force protection, and TOKEN_EXPIRATION_HOURS for JWT token validity. Explain CORS_ORIGINS configuration for cross-origin resource sharing security, emphasizing the risks of wildcard origins in production. Document BCRYPT_ROUNDS for password hashing security and the secure handling of DEFAULT_ADMIN credentials. Include the implementation details from config.py where these values are loaded and validated. Provide secure configuration examples for production environments, showing restricted CORS origins and strong password policies. Address common security misconfigurations such as using default admin passwords, insufficient rate limiting, or overly permissive CORS settings. Include guidance on the secure generation of SECRET_KEY using Python's secrets module and the importance of environment-specific security configurations.

wiki_catalogs.name: MinIO/S3 Storage Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for configuring MinIO or S3-compatible storage in the Vertex AR system. Explain the STORAGE_TYPE='minio' setting and its implications on system behavior. Document each required parameter: MINIO_ENDPOINT (including protocol and port), MINIO_ACCESS_KEY and MINIO_SECRET_KEY (with emphasis on security best practices), MINIO_BUCKET (naming conventions and creation prerequisites), and MINIO_SECURE (boolean flag for HTTPS enforcement). Cover the optional MINIO_PUBLIC_URL for CDN integration and its impact on asset delivery performance and caching. Include real-world examples from development and production .env files, highlighting differences in endpoint URLs and security settings. Detail the validation logic in config.py that loads these values with defaults. Address common configuration pitfalls such as incorrect endpoint formatting, bucket accessibility issues, and SSL/TLS handshake failures. Provide troubleshooting guidance for connectivity problems, signature mismatches, and performance tuning for large file transfers.

wiki_catalogs.name: CORS Security
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) security configuration in the Vertex AR application. Explain the purpose of CORS_ORIGINS and how it controls which domains can access the API. Document the security implications of using wildcard origins (*) in production environments and provide examples of secure origin configurations for different deployment scenarios. Include implementation details from middleware.py showing how CORS headers are applied to responses. Provide guidance on configuring multiple origins for complex deployments with admin interfaces, mobile apps, and third-party integrations. Address common security misconfigurations such as overly permissive origins, missing HTTPS enforcement, and failure to update origins during domain changes. Include examples of production-ready CORS configurations and troubleshooting steps for CORS-related errors. Explain the relationship between CORS configuration and other security measures like CSRF protection and authentication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Telegram Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for Telegram notification integration in the Vertex AR system. Explain the purpose and configuration of TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN and TELEGRAM_CHAT_ID environment variables, including step-by-step instructions for creating a bot via BotFather and obtaining the chat ID for a specific group or user. Describe how to enable or disable Telegram alerts using the NOTIFICATION_TELEGRAM_ENABLED flag. Document the CRITICAL_NOTIFICATION_ROUTES and HIGH_NOTIFICATION_ROUTES settings that determine when Telegram messages are sent. Provide Python code examples demonstrating how the application sends alerts using the python-telegram-bot library. Include security considerations for protecting the bot token, such as restricting IP access and avoiding public exposure in repositories. Address common issues like invalid tokens, unauthorized chat IDs, network connectivity problems, and message rate limits. Show sample alert formats and explain how to customize notification content and severity levels.

wiki_catalogs.name: Caching Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for caching configuration and optimization in the Vertex AR system. Cover the CACHE_ENABLED flag, REDIS_URL connection string, CACHE_TTL (time-to-live), CACHE_NAMESPACE (key organization), and CACHE_MAX_SIZE (memory limits) for both Redis and in-memory caching backends. Explain the implementation in vertex-ar/app/cache.py including cache hit/miss patterns, eviction strategies, and serialization formats. Provide configuration examples for development, staging, and production environments. Include performance metrics for different cache sizes and TTL values, and guidance on monitoring cache efficiency. Address common issues such as cache stampedes, memory bloat, and stale data. Document integration with frequently accessed endpoints like portrait retrieval and company configuration, and provide best practices for cache invalidation strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alert Stabilization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the alert stabilization mechanisms in the Vertex AR monitoring system. Explain the implementation of alert deduplication using MONITORING_DEDUP_WINDOW and consecutive failure counting with MONITORING_CONSECUTIVE_FAILURES to prevent alert storms. Document the _should_escalate_alert method that implements hysteresis logic to ensure alerts are only sent after multiple consecutive failures and within defined cooldown periods. wiki_catalogs.name: Alerting Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the alerting integration system in Vertex AR. Explain the AlertManager class implementation that sends notifications via Telegram and email channels. Document the send_telegram_alert and send_email_alert methods, including their integration with the notification configuration system and fallback to environment variables. Cover the send_alert method that implements multi-channel notification with severity-based formatting and the _get_routes_for_priority method that routes alerts based on NOTIFICATION_*_ROUTES settings. Explain the test_alert_system functionality for validating alert configurations. Detail the integration with the external Alertmanager configuration in alertmanager.yml for routing and notification policies. Include configuration examples for different alerting scenarios and explain how to troubleshoot common delivery issues such as authentication failures and network connectivity problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Network Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for network monitoring in the Vertex AR application. Explain the implementation of the get_network_stats() method that collects comprehensive network interface statistics using psutil, including bytes/packets sent/received, error rates, drop rates, and connection status. Document the analysis of network connections by state (LISTEN, ESTABLISHED, etc.) and tracking of listening ports. Describe how network interface details such as IP addresses, MTU, speed, and duplex mode are collected. Explain the integration with Prometheus for exposing network metrics via the /metrics endpoint and visualization in Grafana. Include configuration examples for monitoring network performance and handling connectivity issues. Address common problems such as high error rates, packet loss, port conflicts, and bandwidth saturation, providing diagnostic procedures and optimization techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Memory Snapshots
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the memory snapshot feature using tracemalloc in the Vertex AR monitoring system. Detail the implementation of automatic memory profiling that triggers when the application's RSS exceeds MONITORING_TRACEMALLOC_THRESHOLD_MB. Explain how the check_and_snapshot_memory method initializes tracemalloc when MONITORING_TRACEMALLOC_ENABLED is set, captures heap snapshots, and analyzes the top MONITORING_TRACEMALLOC_TOP_N memory allocations by file and line number. Document the rate-limiting mechanism that prevents excessive snapshots (limited to one per minute) and the storage of up to 20 historical snapshots. Describe how the get_hotspots method exposes this data and how the manual memory-snapshot API endpoint allows on-demand profiling. Include configuration examples for production and debugging scenarios, emphasizing the ~10% performance overhead. Explain how to interpret the top allocations data to identify memory leaks and inefficient memory usage patterns, and provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like snapshots not triggering as expected.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alert Cooldown and Deduplication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the alert cooldown and deduplication mechanisms in Vertex AR. Explain the should_send_alert method that implements a 300-second cooldown period between identical alert types using the last_alerts dictionary to track timestamps. Document the integration with the system-wide deduplication window controlled by NOTIFICATION_DEDUP_WINDOW (default 300 seconds) and overridable by MONITORING_DEDUP_WINDOW. Describe how consecutive failure tracking requires N consecutive failures (configurable via MONITORING_CONSECUTIVE_FAILURES) before escalation, preventing noise from transient spikes. Cover the health data consistency feature that mirrors alert_manager sends in health_data['alerts'] with transient flags for non-escalated issues. Provide configuration examples for different environments (development, production, high-traffic) and explain how to troubleshoot issues with alert suppression or delayed notifications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the AR backend system. Describe the high-level design as a modular, domain-driven service with clear separation of concerns. Document the layered architecture: API layer, business services, data access, and storage adapters. Explain key architectural patterns: Adapter Pattern for storage backends, Dependency Injection via config objects, Singleton pattern for shared services, and Asynchronous Processing for background tasks. Illustrate component interactions, data flows, and integration patterns with diagrams. Explain critical design decisions, trade-offs (e.g., synchronous vs asynchronous operations), and scalability considerations. Include deployment topology, infrastructure requirements, and cross-cutting concerns like security, monitoring, and disaster recovery.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cloud Provider Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create cloud-specific deployment documentation for hosting the AR application on cloud-ru infrastructure. Cover prerequisites such as SSH access, firewall rules, and domain setup. Include post-deployment verification steps, performance considerations, and scaling recommendations. Compare basic vs improved deployment scripts and their respective use cases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Video Scheduling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Video Scheduling, covering the automated rotation and animation of video content based on time-based rules. wiki_catalogs.name: Storage Management API

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Vertex-AR

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
The Vertex-AR project is a backend service platform designed to support augmented reality (AR) content management, storage orchestration, and multi-tenant company administration. It provides APIs for mobile integration, NFT generation, video scheduling, and remote storage management with Yandex.Disk and MinIO.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Enable AR content delivery and marker management for mobile applications
- Support multi-company tenant isolation with customizable storage and backup configurations
- Implement robust monitoring, alerting, and notification systems
- Facilitate automated workflows for video processing, NFT creation, and data synchronization
- Ensure secure, scalable deployment via Docker, systemd, and cloud infrastructure

### Target Audience
- **Administrators**: Managing company accounts, storage settings, and system health
- **Developers**: Integrating with the API for AR features, NFTs, and media processing
- **Mobile App Teams**: Consuming mobile-optimized endpoints and SDKs
- **DevOps Engineers**: Deploying, monitoring, and maintaining production instances

---

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The system follows a modular backend architecture with clear separation of concerns:

- **API Layer**: RESTful endpoints organized by domain (users, companies, storage, AR, notifications)
- **Service Layer**: Business logic encapsulated in services (email queue, folder management)
- **Storage Abstraction**: Multiple backend support (local, MinIO, Yandex.Disk) via adapters
- **Monitoring Stack**: Prometheus, Grafana, Alertmanager integration
- **Task Automation**: Backup scheduling, email processing, lifecycle management
- **Configuration Management**: Environment variables, JSON config files, `.env` templates

### Design Patterns
- **Modular Package Structure**: Domain-driven design with `app/api`, `services`, and utility modules
- **Dependency Injection via Config**: Centralized configuration object used across components
- **Adapter Pattern**: For pluggable storage backends (`storage_local.py`, `storage_minio.py`, `storage_yandex.py`)
- **Singleton Services**: Email queue and folder service initialized once and reused
- **Asynchronous Processing**: Background tasks for email, backups, and video generation

### System Relationships
```mermaid
graph TD
  A[Client/Mobile App] --> B[API Layer]
  B --> C[Business Logic]
  C --> D[Storage Adapters]
  D --> E[(Local/MinIO/Yandex)]
  C --> F[Database]
  C --> G[Email Service]
  G --> H[Email Queue]
  I[Monitoring] --> J[Prometheus]
  J --> K[Grafana Dashboard]
  L[Scheduler] --> M[Backup Jobs]
  L --> N[Video Animation Scheduler]
  O[Alertmanager] --> P[Notifications]
```

### Data Flow Diagram
```mermaid
flowchart TD
  Client[Client] -->|HTTP Request| API[API Layer]
  API -->|Validate & Route| Service[Business Logic]
  Service -->|Query/Update| DB[(Database)]
  Service -->|Read/Write| Storage[(Storage Backend)]
  Service -->|Enqueue| EmailQueue[Email Queue]
  EmailQueue -->|Background Worker| EmailService[Email Service]
  Service -->|Metrics| Prometheus[Prometheus Metrics]
  Service -->|Log Events| Logging[Structured Logging]
  Scheduler -->|Periodic Tasks| Backup[Backup System]
  Monitoring -->|Scrape| Metrics[Application Metrics]
```

---

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `vertex-ar/app/main.py`: Primary FastAPI application instance and route registration
- `vertex-ar/main.py`: Alternative main module (potential duplication or legacy entry point)
- `vertex-ar/start.sh`: Startup script for production deployment
- `vertex-ar/deploy.sh`: Deployment orchestration script

Sources:
- [main.py](vertex-ar/app/main.py)
- [start.sh](vertex-ar/start.sh)
- [deploy.sh](vertex-ar/deploy.sh)

### Core Modules
- **API Endpoints**: Modularized under `vertex-ar/app/api/` (admin, ar, auth, backups, companies, etc.)
- **Storage System**: Pluggable backends in `storage_*.py` files with adapter pattern
- **Email Queue**: Asynchronous email processing via `services/email_queue.py`
- **Monitoring & Alerting**: Integrated with Prometheus and Alertmanager
- **Backup & Lifecycle Management**: Scheduled jobs and retention policies

Sources:
- [api](vertex-ar/app/api/)
- [storage.py](vertex-ar/storage.py)
- [email_queue.py](vertex-ar/app/services/email_queue.py)
- [backup_scheduler.py](vertex-ar/backup_scheduler.py)

### Configuration Approach
- **Environment Variables**: `.env.example` and `.env.production.example` define required variables
- **JSON Configuration Files**: `config/storage_config.json`, `remote_storage.example.json`
- **Docker & Compose**: `docker-compose.yml`, `docker-compose.minio-remote.yml`
- **Systemd Services**: `systemd/vertex-ar-backup.service` and timer for cron-like scheduling

Sources:
- [.env.example](vertex-ar/.env.example)
- [storage_config.json](vertex-ar/config/storage_config.json)
- [docker-compose.yml](docker-compose.yml)
- [vertex-ar-backup.service](vertex-ar/systemd/vertex-ar-backup.service)

### External Dependencies
- **FastAPI**: Modern Python web framework (declared in `pyproject.toml`)
- **Uvicorn**: ASGI server for high-performance API serving
- **Prometheus Client**: For metrics collection and exposure
- **MinIO SDK**: For S3-compatible object storage
- **Yandex.Disk API**: Remote storage integration
- **psutil**: System monitoring and resource tracking

Sources:
- [pyproject.toml](vertex-ar/pyproject.toml)
- [requirements.txt](vertex-ar/requirements.txt)

### Integration Points
- **Mobile API**: Dedicated endpoints and schema in `/docs/api/mobile-*`
- **Yandex.Disk**: Bidirectional sync and backup via `storage_yandex.py`
- **Email Services**: Queue-based asynchronous delivery with retry logic
- **Monitoring Stack**: Exposed `/metrics` endpoint for Prometheus scraping
- **NFT Generation**: JavaScript and Python tooling (`generate-nft.js`, `nft_maker.py`)

Sources:
- [mobile-api-schema.json](docs/api/mobile-api-schema.json)
- [storage_yandex.py](vertex-ar/storage_yandex.py)
- [email_service.py](vertex-ar/email_service.py)
- [prometheus_metrics.py](vertex-ar/app/prometheus_metrics.py)

### Component Relationship Diagram
```mermaid
graph LR
  API[API Layer] --> Services[Business Services]
  API --> DB[Database Layer]
  Services --> Storage[Storage Adapters]
  Storage --> Local[Local Storage]
  Storage --> MinIO[MinIO]
  Storage --> Yandex[Yandex.Disk]
  Services --> Email[Email Queue]
  Email --> SMTP[SMTP Service]
  Services --> Monitoring[Prometheus Metrics]
  Monitoring --> Grafana[Grafana]
  Monitoring --> Alertmanager[Alertmanager]
  Scheduler[Cron/Scheduler] --> Backups[Backup Jobs]
  Backups --> Storage
  API --> Auth[Authentication]
  Auth --> JWT[JWT Tokens]
```

---

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
- **AR Content Management**: Marker handling, NFT generation, and mobile API support
- **Multi-Company Tenancy**: Isolated configurations, storage defaults, and contact fields
- **Flexible Storage Orchestration**: Local, MinIO, and Yandex.Disk with dynamic routing
- **Automated Backups**: Scheduled, configurable, and remotely storable
- **Video Scheduling**: Animation and preview generation workflows
- **Comprehensive Monitoring**: Health checks, alert deduplication, and web diagnostics
- **Notification Center**: Configurable alerts and user-facing notifications

### Implementation Highlights
- **NFT Generation Pipeline**: Combines Python backend with Node.js scripting (`nft_maker.py`, `generate-nft.js`)
- **Dynamic Folder Provisioning**: Per-company folder structures with validation
- **Remote Storage Flow**: Configurable routing with fallback and redundancy
- **Email Queue Resilience**: Persistent queue with retry and error handling
- **Lifecycle Scheduler**: Time-based automation for content and storage management

Sources:
- [nft_maker.py](vertex-ar/nft_maker.py)
- [generate-nft.js](vertex-ar/generate-nft.js)
- [folder_service.py](vertex-ar/app/services/folder_service.py)
- [remote_storage.py](vertex-ar/remote_storage.py)
- [video_animation_scheduler.py](vertex-ar/app/video_animation_scheduler.py)

### Feature Architecture Diagram
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> Idle
  Idle --> AR_Request: Mobile App Request
  AR_Request --> Validate: Auth & Input Check
  Validate --> Process: Generate Marker/NFT
  Process --> Store: Save to Selected Backend
  Store --> Notify: Send Confirmation
  Notify --> Idle: Complete
  Process --> Error: Failure
  Error --> Retry: Automatic Retry
  Retry --> Process
  Retry --> Alert: Escalate After Threshold
  Alert --> Idle
```

</blog>
